cards.front: State the formula for average power P in an AC circuit.
cards.back: P = ½VmIm·cos(θv - θi) = Vrms·Irms·cos(θv - θi). The cos term is the power factor.

cards.front: What is the RMS value of Vm·cos(ωt + φ)?
cards.back: Vrms = Vm/√2 ≈ 0.707·Vm. RMS = Root Mean Square of the periodic signal.
pf = cos(θv - θi) = P/S. It's the ratio of real power to apparent power, ranging from 0 to 1.

cards.front: What is the difference between lagging and leading power factor?
cards.back: Lagging: current lags voltage (inductive load, Q > 0). Leading: current leads voltage (capacitive load, Q < 0). Always specify which!
S = Vrms·Irms = |S| (magnitude of complex power). Unit: VA (volt-amperes). It's the maximum possible real power if the load were purely resistive.
Q = Vrms·Irms·sin(θv - θi) = Im[S]. Unit: VAR. Positive Q = inductive, negative Q = capacitive. Reactive power does no useful work.

cards.front: State the formula for complex power S.
cards.back: S = P + jQ = ½VI* = Vrms·Irms*. Use the conjugate of I (I*), not I itself!
A right triangle: P (horizontal), Q (vertical), S (hypotenuse). S² = P² + Q². The angle is θv - θi.

cards.front: Why does an ideal inductor absorb zero average power?
cards.back: Z_L = jωL gives a 90° phase difference. P = Vrms·Irms·cos(90°) = 0. Energy is stored in the magnetic field during one quarter-cycle and returned during the next.

cards.front: State the conservation of AC power principle.
cards.back: ΣS_sources = ΣS_loads, meaning both ΣP and ΣQ are individually conserved. Total real power generated = total real power consumed, and same for reactive power.
